children.subject: Same Anon: also I want to work on the software side of things so would this class still be useful?

Thanks for your interest! 

This class, together with the power system classes will be very related to the energy industry. However, this class is mainly focused on electronics. 

This is a more hardware-oriented class so there may not be that many software things that you learn in class. One software thing I can think of is the simulation you will do in labs. So you will work with softwares to understand hardware but I doubt you will write much software. 

Taking this class without the foundation in EE105 is risky because it may also be co-offered as EE290C, meaning there is some difficulty to it. I don't trust myself reading a circuit book over the winter break so if I were in your shoes, I would not take this class. As a side note, EE105 is actually a pretty important foundational class so I wouldn't recommend skipping it.

It's one of those classes that if you don't do circuits, it's "completely" useless but if you are, then you cannot skip it.

Side note: I talked to Professor Sanders a few weeks back about the same concern. I've also taken 7B, and will be enrolled in 105 next semester. He said it should be fine if you're planning on co-enrolling in 105; you may want to speak with him personally if you don't plan on also taking 105.

Junior EECS.  Okay so I think I'm interested in this topic (as I'm thinking I want to work in the energy industry when I graduate), but I have yet to take EE105 (I've taken Physics7B tho).  Can I still take this course IF I read Sedra/Smith’s Microelectronic Circuits, 7th edition cover to cover over winter break?

history.content: Hi everyone, Here is the flyer for EE113 next semester. It's a very practical class. It would be a nice class to take after EE105 if you want to see how microelectronics are applied for power purposes. Given that energy/power is the domain that's been lagging behind all the other developments in EE/CS, it would be cool to learn more about it and potential research areas. flyer
history.subject: EE 113 Power Electronics Promotion
